text: Americans eat on average about 92 pounds
of chicken a year the most popular cut
of chicken is actually boneless skinless
chicken breast but oftentimes they come
out dry and tough like this I have here
well today I'm going to share with you a
foolproof way in cooking boneless
skinless chicken breast and you will
have moist and tender chicken I promise
you I have two boneless skinless chicken
breasts here and I'm using smaller
chicken breasts these are about 5 ounces
each
I prefer smaller because they cook at a
more even rate but if you have bigger
chicken breasts you might have to adopt
this method it's slightly and I'll tell
you how so I'm going to lightly drizzle
the chicken with a little bit of neutral
oil I'm using a safflower oil here
something that doesn't have any flavor
and a good amount of coarse salt and
freshly ground pepper you know before I
was saying that I prefer using smaller
chicken breasts the smaller size really
does help in cooking the chicken breast
evenly if you have something that's so
thick what happens is the high heat it
overcooks the outside of the chicken
while the inside is still undercooked so
a smaller thinner chicken breast will
really cook nice and evenly and in a
short amount of time I have a nice hot
grill pan here and on high high heat now
you can certainly use a saute pan
cast-iron skillet would work just as
well and now I'm gonna place my chicken
breasts right onto the grill pan and
we're gonna cook these about three
minutes per side for a 5 ounce chicken
breast you can rotate them slightly to
get nice crosshatch marks on the chicken
if you'd like that would be half way
through but I'm gonna let these cook 3
minutes and then we're going to flip
them before another 3 minutes so it's
been about 3 minutes and you can start
to see that around the perimeter of the
chicken breast the meat is turning
opaque it's going from that pink
translucent to more of a white opaque
now it's telling you that it's almost
ready to flip so I'm gonna flip this
chicken breast and I'm gonna let it cook
for another 3 minutes
if you're really serious about cooking
chicken and having something that's
moist and tender invest in one of these
it's an instant-read digital thermometer
and this is really the only way in which
you can truly tell if your chicken is
perfectly cooked now often times you
don't know whether or not the
temperature is right well here's a
little trick in making sure that your
digital thermometer is calibrated so you
want a container with a good portion of
ice in it you're gonna put your
thermometer in and what this should read
is somewhere very close to 32 degrees
Fahrenheit or zero degrees Celsius the
temperature it's going down here 33 32
so this is a calibrated thermometer and
it's gonna be true to temperature now
the other way in which you can do that
is with boiling water the temperature
you're looking for is 212 degrees
Fahrenheit or a hundred degrees Celsius
so the chicken breasts have been on for
about another three minutes and now is
the time to check and see if the chicken
is at temperature now the USDA they say
to cook chicken to 165 degrees and I'm
gonna say that you should cook your
chicken breasts to about 160 because the
resting period when you take it off the
heat your chicken will go up another
five degrees I'm going to use my
instant-read thermometer here to check
the internal temperature and you want to
put thermometer in the thickest part of
the breast and it should read 168
degrees so this is great it's a hundred
and sixty degrees so now remember if
your chicken breasts are bigger if
they're bigger than the 5 ounce ones
that I'm using today you want to make
sure that you cook the chicken breast
for another three minutes but then take
it off of the direct heat the grill and
move it to an oven or to a cooler part
of your grill to cook through until it
hits about 160 degrees otherwise you're
gonna overcook the outside of your
chicken and now
the most important part or what have
been most important parts is taking the
chicken off of the heat and allowing it
a few minutes to rest so I'm just gonna
put the chicken breast right here on my
cutting board take a piece of tinfoil
and lightly cover them so they don't
cool down completely you don't want cold
chicken but you do want to give this
about three to four minutes to rest so
all of those wonderful juices they know
run out and leave you with something
that's kind of dry so let this rest it's
been four minutes the chicken breasts
have had time to rest and the juices
have redistributed throughout and cut on
a bias for serving look at that look at
how juicy and delectable this is it's so
simple to cook chicken correctly you
just need to invest in the right
equipment one of those great digital
thermometers and follow these tips so
there you go guys enjoy
you
